awd_titl_txt: Predator control of carrion resources and associated ecological heterogeneity
awd_abstract_narration:
The roles that apex predators play in ecosystems are still debated among researchers and wildlife managers. This project will examine a novel role for these predators, which is their ability to generate hotspots of biological activity by controlling carrion resources. Understanding the diverse functions of apex predators will contribute to sustainable wilderness management, directly enhancing citizen enjoyment and appreciation of wilderness and wildlife for recreation. The project will also advance public awareness of the importance of apex predators, improving societal awareness of wilderness and wildlife preservation. Efforts to maintain carrion resources will help to sustain other species and ecosystem health. The investigators will work with wildlife managers in US National Parks to develop educational maps for outreach and interpretation. Animal remains and scavenger activity created at carcass sites are visually captivating to students of all ages. Investigators will partner with the Western Upper Peninsula Michigan Center for Science, Mathematics and Environmental Education to create a regional remote camera lending depot and lesson plans for recording biological activity at carcass sites. These activities will engage K-12 educators and students in the field of carrion ecology.

Carrion occurs in all biomes. It represents a bottleneck in the vital flow of energy and limiting nutrients with profound ecological and evolutionary consequences. Carrion constitutes a critical resource for a variety of communities and it strongly affects scavenger guilds, the maintenance of biodiversity, and fundamental ecological processes. This research will investigate the poorly understood role of predation in controlling carrion resources, shaping carcass distributions, and generating a shifting mosaic of biogeochemical and community activity. Two interrelated sets of questions will be addressed across four terrestrial ecosystems: 1) How do carrion-derived effects vary across multiple ecosystems and across a diversity of predator-prey communities? And 2) How does predation influence carrion distribution across space and time? Experiments and field studies will reveal above and belowground carrion effects across key biomes. This understanding will be coupled with spatial records of carcasses to examine predator control of carrion resources across multiple scales. Data from experiments, field studies and carcass records will be incorporated into spatial models to examine predator-carrion dynamics and predation controls over carrion resource flow compared to die-offs. The focal systems span a range of ecosystems and predator-prey diversity, and will yield both general patterns and identify distinct differences in predator control of carrion resources across biomes.  In examining predator control of carrion resources, this work addresses both the fundamental focus in ecology on  mechanisms of trophic control of community and ecosystem structure and explores a novel concept that can add to a comprehensive view of the ecological role of predators.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
Ecologists continue to debate the importance of predation in driving community dynamics, in part due to a traditional view that ecological heterogeneity is governed primarily by physical factors. Additionally, a prio lack of data led to limited mechanistic understanding to assess whether the role of predators is indeed as important as physical forcing. This research project scrutinized a novel but unexamined mechanism: whether predation alters community structure by affecting the spatial heterogeneity of biological activity, nutrient inputs, and disturbance associated with carrion resources. We used experiments, field sampling, modeling, and unprecedented database development to develop a synthetic understanding of how predators control carrion resources and thereby influence vertebrate communities, patterns of disturbance, biogeochemicial hotspots, microbial diversity, and feedbacks to plant communities.  Audio-visual documentation of fieldwork integrated research and broader impact activities, creating a catalyzing window into the intersection of science and education.

Life concentrates biologically limiting resources. Primary producers harness solar energy and earth elements to produce tissues that feed the vast array of herbivores globally. Herbivore tissue, in turn, increases in nutritional value and feeds a diversity of predators across multiple trophic levels. In death, animal tissues are consumed or re-enter the cycle via decomposition, thereby dispersing biologically limiting resources. This simplification of global resource cycling via biological pathways highlights the fundamental importance of dead animal matter (carrion; e.g. vertebrate carcasses) in maintaining biodiversity and ecological processes, especially in terrestrial ecosystems.

Until mortality, consumers temporarily concentrate and sequester energy and nutrients in their standing biomass. Carrion occurs in all biomes and can be conceptualized as a bottleneck in the vital flow of energy and limiting nutrients with profound ecological and evolutionary consequences. Moreover, carrion strongly affects scavenger guilds, the maintenance of soil and plant biodiversity, and the availability of biogeochemical hotspots.

Surprisingly, through this project we have learned that even very well consumed carrion can result in strong ecological effects – equally and sometimes exceeding effects associated with urine and fecal inputs – that last multiple years and shape biotic communities and ecosystem processes. While carrion effects and feedbacks are discrete, their ecological consequences have been considered analogous to a rhizosphere or drilosphere, because although a ‘carcassphere’ is a small proportion of terrestrial area, it can account for a biologically significant amount of heterotrophic activity within an ecosystem. This research project revealed how predation and human actions influence carrion resources in space and time, including the subsequent effects of carrion on soil and plant community structure, nutrient cycling, and carbon respiration. As a result this work made key contributions to the synthetic understanding of the functional role of large terrestrial predators in order to advance community ecology and conservation science. In particular project findings help to determin the conditions that lead to mechanistic links between predation patterns and nutrient/disturbance heterogeneity that creates biogeochemicial hotspots that sustain microbial diversity and feedback to plant communities.

An important way by which predators exert control over carrion is through their influence on the spatial distribution of carrion patterns across landscapes and throughout an annual timeframe. The spatial distribution (e.g., heterogeneous vs. homogenous) of limiting resources is known to be an important determinant of plant diversity and productivity and soil nutrient storage. Predators may introduce substantial and lasting heterogeneity by creating biogeochemical hotspots at kill sites, which causes spatial heterogeneity in nutrient cycling rates and elemental composition of vegetation, and altered animal activity, especially that of facultative scavengers. The novel work of this project helped establish the generality of predator control of carrion resources and disturbance. In this way, this work intellectuall transformed our understanding of how predation and abiotic controls interact to influence resource heterogeneity. Understanding predation’s control of carrion dynamics and resource heterogeneity is an important focus in ecology and necessary for predicting contingent outcomes in nature and for maintaining ecological processes such as mosaics of resource heterogeneity that help maintain microbial and plant diversity. Additionally, because predators and carrion are impacted by human activities and environmental change, such an understanding has significant implications for the conservation of predators and the management of carrion across terrestrial systems.

Recent calls for a paradigm shift about the importance of predation rely on classic mechanisms of consumptive control of prey populations that result in trophic cascades and non-consumptive ‘fear’ mechanisms that structure prey space use. Yet, this work identified a new mechanism that transforms our perspective on predation. 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/16/2024
Modified by: Joseph K Bump

  • Select array of additional scavengers and other species observed on elephant carcasses in Tsavo, Kenya. A. a white-headed vulture with a pair of wooly-necked storks, B. a striped hyena, C. an Egyptian goose, D. a black-backed jackal, E. a Palm-nut vulture, F. A hippo scavenging.
    Aaron Morris
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Joseph K Bump
    Eating an elephant, one bite at a time: Predator interactions at carrion bonanzas
  • Carcasses of African elephants often persist long enough to allow blowfly species to complete their life cycle en masse. The presence of tens of thousands of blowflies and other carrion-associated arthropods attracts species that are typically unaffiliated with carrion, such as superb starlings.
    Aaron Morris
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Joseph K Bump
    Superb Carrion
  • Mass�balance approaches provide a top-down approach to estimate carrion biomass as a function of changes to steady-state conditions. Key metrics: ecosystem carrion estimates provide data about total quantities and turnover.
    Philip Barton
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Joseph K Bump
    Linkages between Individual Carcasses, Populations, Communities, and Ecosystems Can Facilitate Estimation of Carrion Biomass at Each Scale
  • A fox den (A), wolf defecating on a fox den (B), a raven stealing feathers a den (C), bald eagles sparring over prey remains from a den (D), a polar bear consuming prey remains on a den (E), caribou foraging on a den in late spring (F).
    Sean Johnson-Bice
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Joseph K Bump
    A collection of photos from Arctic fox dens near Churchill, Manitoba, Canada. Arctic fox dens are distinct biogeochemical patches with lush vegetation that stands out prominently on the tundra
  • Localised carcass effects included elevated soil nutrients, microbial biomass and plant nitrogen. Understanding how wolves contributed to carcass effects across the island landscape (lower and upper right) was achieved by relating carcasses from wolf kills versus natural starvation.
    Joseph Bump
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Joseph K Bump
    Scaling of Local to Landscape Carrion Effects Was Undertaken at Isle Royale National Park, USA, by Quantifying the Long-Term (1958�2016) Influence of Wolves on Carrion Resource Heterogeneity via Moose Carcass Distribution
